dn24:1.1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā mallesu viharati anupiyaṃ nāma mallānaṃ nigamo.
dn24:1.1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Anupiya.
dn24:1.1.2.comm: This late sutta satirizes the failings of Sunakkhatta in a fashion so broad that it borders on slapstick. The town of Anupiya is mentioned only here.

dn24:1.1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya anupiyaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
dn24:1.1.3.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Anupiya for alms.

dn24:1.1.5.eng: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Anupiya.

dn24:1.1.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena bhaggavagottassa paribbājakassa ārāmo, yena bhaggavagotto paribbājako tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
dn24:1.1.6.eng: Why don’t I go to visit the wanderer of the Bhaggava clan in his monastery?”
dn24:1.1.6.comm: The Bhaggava clan was descended from the ancient sage Bhagu (Sanskrit Bhṛgu). They received the gift of fire conveyed by Mātariśvan the wind from the god Agni (eg. Rig Veda 1.60.1). In Pali they appear as potters (eg. MN 81:19.3, MN 140:1.3, SN 1.50:11.2, SN 2.24:12.2). Archaeologists refer to the strata around the Buddha’s time as the Northern Black Polished Ware culture on account of the distinctive highly glazed polish that was achieved on the pottery of the time. This, together with the production of iron, marked a significant advance in the mastery of fire. Thus potters were no mere humble craftsmen, but leading technological innovators.

dn24:1.2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena bhaggavagottassa paribbājakassa ārāmo, yena bhaggavagotto paribbājako tenupasaṅkami.

dn24:1.2.2.pli: Atha kho bhaggavagotto paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn24:1.2.2.eng: Then the wanderer of the Bhaggava clan said to the Buddha,

dn24:1.2.4.eng: Welcome to the Blessed One, sir!

dn24:1.2.5.pli: Cirassaṃ kho, bhante, bhagavā imaṃ pariyāyamakāsi yadidaṃ idhāgamanāya.
dn24:1.2.5.eng: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.

dn24:1.2.6.eng: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”

dn24:1.2.7.eng: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,

dn24:1.2.8.pli: Bhaggavagottopi kho paribbājako aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn24:1.2.8.eng: while the wanderer of the Bhaggava clan took a low seat, sat to one side,

dn24:1.2.9.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho bhaggavagotto paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

dn24:1.2.10.pli: “purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ etadavoca:
dn24:1.2.10.eng: “Sir, a few days ago Sunakkhatta the Licchavi came to me and said:
dn24:1.2.10.comm: Sunakkhatta’s dismal spiritual career began when he met the Buddha in MN 105. In DN 6:5.3 we learn that, after being ordained three years, he spoke of his limited success in meditation. The current sutta and MN 12 deal with Sunakkhatta’s bitter criticisms of the Buddha shortly after his disrobal.

dn24:1.2.11.eng: ‘Now, Bhaggava, I have disavowed the Buddha.

dn24:1.2.12.eng: Now I no longer live dedicated to him.’

dn24:1.2.13.pli: Kaccetaṃ, bhante, tatheva, yathā sunakkhatto licchaviputto avacā”ti?
dn24:1.2.13.eng: Sir, is what Sunakkhatta said true?”

dn24:1.2.14.pli: “Tatheva kho etaṃ, bhaggava, yathā sunakkhatto licchaviputto avaca.

dn24:1.3.1.pli: Purimāni, bhaggava, divasāni purimatarāni sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto maṃ etadavoca:
dn24:1.3.1.eng: A few days ago Sunakkhatta the Licchavi came to me, bowed, sat down to one side, and said:

dn24:1.3.3.pli: Na dānāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ uddissa viharissāmī’ti.
dn24:1.3.3.eng: Now I shall no longer live dedicated to you.’

dn24:1.3.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhaggava, sunakkhattaṃ licchaviputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn24:1.3.4.eng: When Sunakkhatta said this, I said to him,

dn24:1.3.5.eng: ‘But Sunakkhatta, did I ever say to you:

dn24:1.3.6.pli: ehi tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, mamaṃ uddissa viharāhī’ti?
dn24:1.3.6.comm: A candidate for ordination is expected to go for refuge to the Buddha, and may be said to live dedicated (uddissa) to him (Kd 1:23.4.1). Moreover, a noble disciple is unable to dedicate themselves to another teacher (AN 1.276:1.1). But when the Buddha called candidates to go forth, he spoke of practice rather than personal devotion: “Come, monk. The Teaching is well-proclaimed. Practice the spiritual life to make a complete end of suffering.” (Kd 1:6.32.3)

dn24:1.3.8.eng: ‘Or did you ever say to me:

dn24:1.3.9.eng: “Sir, I shall live dedicated to the Buddha”?’

dn24:1.3.11.eng: ‘So it seems that I did not ask you to

dn24:1.3.12.pli: ehi tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, mamaṃ uddissa viharāhīti.

dn24:1.3.13.eng: nor did you say you would

dn24:1.3.15.pli: Evaṃ sante, moghapurisa, ko santo kaṃ paccācikkhasi?
dn24:1.3.15.eng: In that case, you futile man, who are you and what do you want to disavow?

dn24:1.3.16.pli: Passa, moghapurisa, yāvañca te idaṃ aparaddhan’ti.
dn24:1.3.16.eng: See how far you have strayed!’

dn24:1.4.1.pli: ‘Na hi pana me, bhante, bhagavā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karotī’ti.
dn24:1.4.1.eng: ‘But sir, the Buddha never performs any superhuman demonstrations of psychic power for me.’
dn24:1.4.1.comm: He makes a similar criticism at MN 12:3.8.

dn24:1.4.2.eng: ‘But Sunakkhatta, did I ever say to you:

dn24:1.4.3.pli: ehi tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, mamaṃ uddissa viharāhi, ahaṃ te uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissāmī’ti?
dn24:1.4.3.eng: “Come, live dedicated to me and I will perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power for you”?’

dn24:1.4.5.eng: ‘Or did you ever say to me:

dn24:1.4.6.pli: ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ uddissa viharissāmi, bhagavā me uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissatī’ti?
dn24:1.4.6.eng: “Sir, I shall live dedicated to the Buddha, and the Buddha will perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power for me”?’

dn24:1.4.8.eng: ‘So it seems that I did not ask this of you, and you did not require it of me.

dn24:1.4.9.pli: ehi tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, mamaṃ uddissa viharāhi, ahaṃ te uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissāmīti;

dn24:1.4.11.pli: ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ uddissa viharissāmi, bhagavā me uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissatīti.

dn24:1.4.12.pli: Evaṃ sante, moghapurisa, ko santo kaṃ paccācikkhasi?
dn24:1.4.12.eng: In that case, you futile man, who are you and what do you want to disavow?

dn24:1.4.14.pli: kate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye akate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye yassatthāya mayā dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti?
dn24:1.4.14.eng: Whether or not there is a demonstration of psychic power, does my teaching lead someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering?’

dn24:1.4.15.pli: ‘Kate vā, bhante, uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye akate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye yassatthāya bhagavatā dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti.

dn24:1.4.16.pli: ‘Iti kira, sunakkhatta, kate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye, akate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye, yassatthāya mayā dhammo desito, so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
dn24:1.4.16.eng: ‘So it seems that whether or not there is a demonstration of psychic power, my teaching leads someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering.

dn24:1.4.17.pli: Tatra, sunakkhatta, kiṃ uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ kataṃ karissati?
dn24:1.4.17.eng: In that case, what is the point of superhuman demonstrations of psychic power?

dn24:1.4.18.pli: Passa, moghapurisa, yāvañca te idaṃ aparaddhan’ti.
dn24:1.4.18.eng: See how far you have strayed, you silly man!’

dn24:1.5.1.pli: ‘Na hi pana me, bhante, bhagavā aggaññaṃ paññapetī’ti?
dn24:1.5.1.eng: ‘But sir, the Buddha never describes the origin of the world to me.’

dn24:1.5.2.eng: ‘But Sunakkhatta, did I ever say to you:

dn24:1.5.3.pli: ehi tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, mamaṃ uddissa viharāhi, ahaṃ te aggaññaṃ paññapessāmī’ti?
dn24:1.5.3.eng: “Come, live dedicated to me and I will describe the origin of the world to you”?’

dn24:1.5.5.eng: ‘Or did you ever say to me:

dn24:1.5.6.pli: ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ uddissa viharissāmi, bhagavā me aggaññaṃ paññapessatī’ti?
dn24:1.5.6.eng: “Sir, I shall live dedicated to the Buddha, and the Buddha will describe the origin of the world to me”?’

dn24:1.5.8.eng: ‘So it seems that I did not ask this of you, and you did not require it of me.

dn24:1.5.9.pli: ehi tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, mamaṃ uddissa viharāhi, ahaṃ te aggaññaṃ paññapessāmīti.

dn24:1.5.11.pli: ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ uddissa viharissāmi, bhagavā me aggaññaṃ paññapessatīti.

dn24:1.5.12.pli: Evaṃ sante, moghapurisa, ko santo kaṃ paccācikkhasi?
dn24:1.5.12.eng: In that case, you futile man, who are you and what do you want to disavow?

dn24:1.5.14.pli: paññatte vā aggaññe, apaññatte vā aggaññe, yassatthāya mayā dhammo desito, so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti?
dn24:1.5.14.eng: Whether or not the origin of the world is described, does my teaching lead someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering?’

dn24:1.5.15.pli: ‘Paññatte vā, bhante, aggaññe, apaññatte vā aggaññe, yassatthāya bhagavatā dhammo desito, so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti.

dn24:1.5.16.pli: ‘Iti kira, sunakkhatta, paññatte vā aggaññe, apaññatte vā aggaññe, yassatthāya mayā dhammo desito, so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
dn24:1.5.16.eng: ‘So it seems that whether or not the origin of the world is described, my teaching leads someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering.

dn24:1.5.17.pli: Tatra, sunakkhatta, kiṃ aggaññaṃ paññattaṃ karissati?
dn24:1.5.17.eng: In that case, what is the point of describing the origin of the world?

dn24:1.5.18.pli: Passa, moghapurisa, yāvañca te idaṃ aparaddhaṃ.
dn24:1.5.18.eng: See how far you have strayed, you silly man!

dn24:1.6.1.pli: Anekapariyāyena kho te, sunakkhatta, mama vaṇṇo bhāsito vajjigāme—
dn24:1.6.1.eng: In many ways, Sunakkhatta, you have praised me like this in the Vajjian capital:

dn24:1.6.2.pli: itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
dn24:1.6.2.eng: “That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.”

dn24:1.6.3.pli: Iti kho te, sunakkhatta, anekapariyāyena mama vaṇṇo bhāsito vajjigāme.

dn24:1.6.4.pli: Anekapariyāyena kho te, sunakkhatta, dhammassa vaṇṇo bhāsito vajjigāme—
dn24:1.6.4.eng: In many ways you have praised the teaching like this in the Vajjian capital:

dn24:1.6.5.pli: svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhīti.
dn24:1.6.5.eng: “The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”

dn24:1.6.6.pli: Iti kho te, sunakkhatta, anekapariyāyena dhammassa vaṇṇo bhāsito vajjigāme.

dn24:1.6.7.pli: Anekapariyāyena kho te, sunakkhatta, saṅghassa vaṇṇo bhāsito vajjigāme—
dn24:1.6.7.eng: In many ways you have praised the Saṅgha like this in the Vajjian capital:

dn24:1.6.8.pli: suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā, esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassāti.
dn24:1.6.8.eng: “The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

dn24:1.6.9.pli: Iti kho te, sunakkhatta, anekapariyāyena saṅghassa vaṇṇo bhāsito vajjigāme.

dn24:1.6.10.pli: Ārocayāmi kho te, sunakkhatta, paṭivedayāmi kho te, sunakkhatta.
dn24:1.6.10.eng: I declare this to you, Sunakkhatta, I announce this to you!

dn24:1.6.11.pli: Bhavissanti kho te, sunakkhatta, vattāro, no visahi sunakkhatto licchaviputto samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ, so avisahanto sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattoti.
dn24:1.6.11.eng: There will be those who say that Sunakkhatta was unable to lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama. That’s why he resigned the training and returned to a lesser life.

dn24:1.6.12.pli: Iti kho te, sunakkhatta, bhavissanti vattāro’ti.

dn24:1.6.13.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto mayā vuccamāno apakkameva imasmā dhammavinayā, yathā taṃ āpāyiko nerayiko.
dn24:1.6.13.eng: Though I spoke to Sunakkhatta like this, he still left this teaching and training, like someone on the highway to hell.

dn24:1.7.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, bhaggava, samayaṃ thūlūsu viharāmi uttarakā nāma thūlūnaṃ nigamo.
dn24:1.7.1.eng: Bhaggava, this one time I was staying in the land of the Kurus where they have a town named Uttarakā.
dn24:1.7.1.comm: There are at least eight spellings for this tribe, including thulu, bumu and khulu. Below we meet a member of the ruling clan of the tribe named korakhattiya. I propose that kora is “of Kuru” by way of secondary derivation; cp. Koravya as a regular name for the kings of Kuru. Thus korakhattiya is not a personal name, but rather “the aristocrat of Kuru”. The name of the city uttarakā means “northern”, and Kuru is indeed northern. Occam’s razor would urge us not to assume the existence of an otherwise unknown tribe on such a dubious term when it can be explained more parsimoniously as an ancient misspelling of Kuru. The Chinese at DA 15 (T 1, 67a15) has 白土 (“white clay”), which does not seem to clear it up.

dn24:1.7.2.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhaggava, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sunakkhattena licchaviputtena pacchāsamaṇena uttarakaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ.
dn24:1.7.2.eng: Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, entered Uttarakā for alms with Sunakkhatta the Licchavi as my second monk.

dn24:1.7.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena acelo korakkhattiyo kukkuravatiko catukkuṇḍiko chamānikiṇṇaṃ bhakkhasaṃ mukheneva khādati, mukheneva bhuñjati.
dn24:1.7.3.eng: Now at that time a naked ascetic who was an aristocrat of Kuru had taken a vow to behave like a dog. When food is tossed on the ground, he gets down on all fours, eating and devouring it just with his mouth.
dn24:1.7.3.comm: This practice is further described, along with the “cow vow”, at MN 57.

dn24:1.7.4.pli: Addasā kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ kukkuravatikaṃ catukkuṇḍikaṃ chamānikiṇṇaṃ bhakkhasaṃ mukheneva khādantaṃ mukheneva bhuñjantaṃ.

dn24:1.7.6.pli: ‘sādhurūpo vata bho ayaṃ samaṇo catukkuṇḍiko chamānikiṇṇaṃ bhakkhasaṃ mukheneva khādati, mukheneva bhuñjatī’ti.
dn24:1.7.6.comm: “Holy man” is sādhurūpo (cp. Dhp 263, AN 6.54:26.1).

dn24:1.7.7.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhaggava, sunakkhattassa licchaviputtassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya sunakkhattaṃ licchaviputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn24:1.7.7.eng: Then, knowing Sunakkhatta’s train of thought, I said to him,

dn24:1.7.8.eng: ‘Don’t you claim to be an ascetic who follows the Sakyan, you silly man?’

dn24:1.7.9.eng: ‘But why does the Buddha say this to me?’

dn24:1.7.11.pli: ‘Nanu te, sunakkhatta, imaṃ acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ kukkuravatikaṃ catukkuṇḍikaṃ chamānikiṇṇaṃ bhakkhasaṃ mukheneva khādantaṃ mukheneva bhuñjantaṃ disvāna etadahosi—
dn24:1.7.11.eng: ‘When you saw that naked ascetic of Kuru, didn’t you think,

dn24:1.7.12.pli: sādhurūpo vata bho ayaṃ samaṇo catukkuṇḍiko chamānikiṇṇaṃ bhakkhasaṃ mukheneva khādati, mukheneva bhuñjatī’ti?

dn24:1.7.14.pli: Kiṃ pana, bhante, bhagavā arahattassa maccharāyatī’ti?
dn24:1.7.14.eng: But sir, are you jealous of the perfected ones?’

dn24:1.7.15.eng: ‘I’m not jealous of the perfected ones, you silly man.

dn24:1.7.16.pli: Api ca tuyhevetaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ, taṃ pajaha.
dn24:1.7.16.eng: Rather, you should give up this harmful misconception that has arisen in you.

dn24:1.7.17.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
dn24:1.7.17.eng: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!

dn24:1.7.18.pli: Yaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, maññasi acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ—sādhurūpo ayaṃ samaṇoti. So sattamaṃ divasaṃ alasakena kālaṃ karissati.
dn24:1.7.18.eng: That naked ascetic the aristocrat of Kuru, who you imagine to be a holy man, will die of flatulence in seven days.
dn24:1.7.18.comm: Alasaka is otherwise unknown in early Pali. Sanskrit medical texts describe it as flatulent indigestion. This agrees with the subcommentary’s ajīraṇena āmarogena (“indigestion”). | In this sutta, the Buddha is depicted as making specific predictions about the future, whereas normally he does not and probably cannot. Rather, he makes conditional predictions that if such courses are pursued, such results will follow.

dn24:1.7.19.pli: Kālaṅkato ca kālakañcikā nāma asurā sabbanihīno asurakāyo, tatra upapajjissati.
dn24:1.7.19.eng: And when he dies, he’ll be reborn in the very lowest rank of titans, named the Kālakañjas.
dn24:1.7.19.comm: The terrifying Kālakañjas are mentioned at DN 20:12.5.

dn24:1.7.20.eng: And they’ll throw him in the charnel ground on a clump of vetiver.

dn24:1.7.21.pli: Ākaṅkhamāno ca tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā puccheyyāsi—
dn24:1.7.21.eng: If you wish, Sunakkhatta, go to the aristocrat of Kuru and ask him

dn24:1.7.22.eng: whether he knows his own destiny.

dn24:1.7.23.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṃ te acelo korakkhattiyo byākarissati—
dn24:1.7.23.eng: It’s possible that he will answer:

dn24:1.7.24.eng: “Reverend Sunakkhatta, I know my own destiny.

dn24:1.7.25.pli: kālakañcikā nāma asurā sabbanihīno asurakāyo, tatrāmhi upapanno’ti.
dn24:1.7.25.eng: I’ve been reborn in the very lowest rank of titans, named the Kālakañjas.”’

dn24:1.8.1.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yena acelo korakkhattiyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ etadavoca:
dn24:1.8.1.eng: So, Bhaggava, Sunakkhatta went to see the aristocrat of Kuru and said to him,

dn24:1.8.2.eng: ‘Reverend aristocrat of Kuru, the ascetic Gotama has declared

dn24:1.8.3.pli: acelo korakkhattiyo sattamaṃ divasaṃ alasakena kālaṃ karissati.
dn24:1.8.3.eng: that you will die of flatulence in seven days.

dn24:1.8.4.pli: Kālaṅkato ca kālakañcikā nāma asurā sabbanihīno asurakāyo, tatra upapajjissati.
dn24:1.8.4.eng: And when you die, you’ll be reborn in the very lowest rank of titans, named the Kālakañjas.

dn24:1.8.5.eng: And when you die, they’ll throw you in the charnel ground on a clump of vetiver.

dn24:1.8.6.pli: Yena tvaṃ, āvuso korakkhattiya, mattaṃ mattañca bhattaṃ bhuñjeyyāsi, mattaṃ mattañca pānīyaṃ piveyyāsi.
dn24:1.8.6.eng: But by eating just a little food and drinking just a little water,

dn24:1.8.7.pli: Yathā samaṇassa gotamassa micchā assa vacanan’ti.
dn24:1.8.7.eng: you’ll prove what the ascetic Gotama says to be false.’

dn24:1.8.8.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto ekadvīhikāya sattarattindivāni gaṇesi, yathā taṃ tathāgatassa asaddahamāno.
dn24:1.8.8.eng: Then Sunakkhatta counted up the days until the seventh day, as happens when you have no faith in the Realized One.

dn24:1.8.9.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, acelo korakkhattiyo sattamaṃ divasaṃ alasakena kālamakāsi.
dn24:1.8.9.eng: But on the seventh day, the naked ascetic who was an aristocrat of Kuru died of flatulence.

dn24:1.8.10.pli: kālaṅkato ca kālakañcikā nāma asurā sabbanihīno asurakāyo, tatra upapajji.
dn24:1.8.10.eng: And when he passed away, he was reborn in the very lowest rank of titans, named the Kālakañjas.

dn24:1.8.11.eng: And when he passed away, they threw him in the charnel ground on a clump of vetiver.

dn24:1.9.1.eng: Sunakkhatta the Licchavi heard about this.

dn24:1.9.2.pli: ‘acelo kira korakkhattiyo alasakena kālaṅkato bīraṇatthambake susāne chaḍḍito’ti.

dn24:1.9.3.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yena bīraṇatthambakaṃ susānaṃ, yena acelo korakkhattiyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ tikkhattuṃ pāṇinā ākoṭesi:
dn24:1.9.3.eng: So he went to see the aristocrat of Kuru in the charnel ground on the clump of vetiver. There he struck him with his fist three times,

dn24:1.9.4.eng: ‘Reverend aristocrat of Kuru, do you know your destiny?’

dn24:1.9.5.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, acelo korakkhattiyo pāṇinā piṭṭhiṃ paripuñchanto vuṭṭhāsi.
dn24:1.9.5.eng: Then the aristocrat of Kuru got up, rubbing his back with his hands, and said,
dn24:1.9.5.comm: This whole passage is unprecedented in early Buddhism. If Sunakkhatta was indeed able to revive the dead with three punches, it would explain why he thought so little of the Buddha’s powers. But the ease with which this information is obtained contrasts with the elaborate failures of Pāyāsi (DN 23).

dn24:1.9.6.eng: ‘Reverend Sunakkhatta, I know my own destiny.

dn24:1.9.7.pli: Kālakañcikā nāma asurā sabbanihīno asurakāyo, tatrāmhi upapanno’ti vatvā tattheva uttāno papati.
dn24:1.9.7.eng: I’ve been reborn in the very lowest rank of titans, named the Kālakañjas.’ After speaking, he fell flat right there.

dn24:1.10.1.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhaggava, sunakkhattaṃ licchaviputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn24:1.10.1.eng: Then Sunakkhatta came to me, bowed, and sat down to one side. I said to him,

dn24:1.10.3.pli: yatheva te ahaṃ acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ ārabbha byākāsiṃ, tatheva taṃ vipākaṃ, aññathā vā’ti?
dn24:1.10.3.eng: Did the prediction I made about the aristocrat of Kuru turn out to be correct, or not?’

dn24:1.10.4.pli: ‘Yatheva me, bhante, bhagavā acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ ārabbha byākāsi, tatheva taṃ vipākaṃ, no aññathā’ti.

dn24:1.10.6.pli: yadi evaṃ sante kataṃ vā hoti uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ, akataṃ vā’ti?
dn24:1.10.6.eng: If that is so, has a superhuman demonstration of psychic power been performed or not?’

dn24:1.10.7.pli: ‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante kataṃ hoti uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ, no akatan’ti.
dn24:1.10.7.eng: ‘Clearly, sir, a superhuman demonstration of psychic power has been performed.’

dn24:1.10.8.pli: ‘Evampi kho maṃ tvaṃ, moghapurisa, uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karontaṃ evaṃ vadesi—
dn24:1.10.8.eng: ‘Though I performed such a superhuman demonstration of psychic power you say this:

dn24:1.10.9.pli: na hi pana me, bhante, bhagavā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karotīti.
dn24:1.10.9.eng: “But sir, the Buddha never performs any superhuman demonstrations of psychic power for me.”

dn24:1.10.10.pli: Passa, moghapurisa, yāvañca te idaṃ aparaddhan’ti.
dn24:1.10.10.eng: See how far you have strayed!’

dn24:1.10.11.pli: Evampi kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto mayā vuccamāno apakkameva imasmā dhammavinayā, yathā taṃ āpāyiko nerayiko.
dn24:1.10.11.eng: Though I spoke to Sunakkhatta like this, he still left this teaching and training, like someone on the highway to hell.

dn24:1.11.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, bhaggava, samayaṃ vesāliyaṃ viharāmi mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
dn24:1.11.1.eng: This one time, Bhaggava, I was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

dn24:1.11.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako vesāliyaṃ paṭivasati lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme.
dn24:1.11.2.eng: Now at that time the naked ascetic Kaḷāramaṭṭaka was residing in Vesālī. And in the Vajjian capital he had reached the peak of material things and fame.

dn24:1.11.3.eng: He had undertaken these seven vows.
dn24:1.11.3.comm: In these practices we see some examples of the vows or observances (vata) that Buddha rejected as “grasping at precepts and observances”

dn24:1.11.4.pli: ‘yāvajīvaṃ acelako assaṃ, na vatthaṃ paridaheyyaṃ, yāvajīvaṃ brahmacārī assaṃ, na methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭiseveyyaṃ, yāvajīvaṃ surāmaṃseneva yāpeyyaṃ, na odanakummāsaṃ bhuñjeyyaṃ.
dn24:1.11.4.eng: ‘As long as I live, I will be a naked ascetic, not wearing clothes. As long as I live, I will be chaste, not having sex. As long as I live, I will consume only meat and beer, not eating rice and porridge.
dn24:1.11.4.comm: A diet of pure meat is still undertaken today by certain would-be gurus.

dn24:1.11.5.pli: Puratthimena vesāliṃ udenaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ, taṃ nātikkameyyaṃ, dakkhiṇena vesāliṃ gotamakaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ, taṃ nātikkameyyaṃ, pacchimena vesāliṃ sattambaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ, taṃ nātikkameyyaṃ, uttarena vesāliṃ bahuputtaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ taṃ nātikkameyyan’ti.
dn24:1.11.5.eng: And I will not go past the following shrines near Vesālī: the Udena Shrine to the east, the Gotamaka to the south, the Seven Maidens to the west, and the Many Sons to the north.’
dn24:1.11.5.comm: Compare the “vow of restraint in the directions” in the Jain Tattvārthasūtra 7.1.

dn24:1.11.6.pli: So imesaṃ sattannaṃ vatapadānaṃ samādānahetu lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme.
dn24:1.11.6.eng: And it was due to undertaking these seven vows that he had reached the peak of material things and fame.

dn24:1.12.1.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yena acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā acelaṃ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṃ pañhaṃ apucchi.
dn24:1.12.1.eng: So, Bhaggava, Sunakkhatta went to see Kaḷāramaṭṭaka and asked him a question.

dn24:1.12.2.pli: Tassa acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako pañhaṃ puṭṭho na sampāyāsi.

dn24:1.12.3.eng: he displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

dn24:1.12.4.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhattassa licchaviputtassa etadahosi:

dn24:1.12.5.eng: ‘I’ve offended the holy man, the perfected one, the ascetic.
dn24:1.12.5.comm: Āsādimhase is middle aorist plural. Below Sunakkhatta again refers to himself in plural, but as usual I render with singular.

dn24:1.12.6.pli: Mā vata no ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā’ti.
dn24:1.12.6.eng: I mustn’t create lasting harm and suffering for myself!’

dn24:1.13.1.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhaggava, sunakkhattaṃ licchaviputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn24:1.13.1.eng: Then Sunakkhatta came to me, bowed, and sat down to one side. I said to him,

dn24:1.13.2.eng: ‘Don’t you claim to be an ascetic who follows the Sakyan, you silly man?’

dn24:1.13.3.eng: ‘But why does the Buddha say this to me?’

dn24:1.13.4.pli: tvampi nāma, moghapurisa, samaṇo sakyaputtiyo paṭijānissasī’ti?

dn24:1.13.5.pli: ‘Nanu tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, acelaṃ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ apucchi.
dn24:1.13.5.eng: ‘Didn’t you go to see the naked ascetic Kaḷāramaṭṭaka and ask him a question?

dn24:1.13.6.pli: Tassa te acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako pañhaṃ puṭṭho na sampāyāsi.

dn24:1.13.7.eng: he displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

dn24:1.13.9.eng: “I’ve offended the holy man, the perfected one, the ascetic.

dn24:1.13.10.pli: Mā vata no ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”’ti.
dn24:1.13.10.eng: I mustn’t create lasting harm and suffering for myself!”’

dn24:1.13.12.pli: Kiṃ pana, bhante, bhagavā arahattassa maccharāyatī’ti?
dn24:1.13.12.eng: But sir, are you jealous of perfected ones?’

dn24:1.13.13.eng: ‘I’m not jealous of the perfected ones, you silly man.

dn24:1.13.14.pli: api ca tuyhevetaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ, taṃ pajaha.
dn24:1.13.14.eng: Rather, you should give up this harmful misconception that has arisen in you.

dn24:1.13.15.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
dn24:1.13.15.eng: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!

dn24:1.13.16.pli: Yaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, maññasi acelaṃ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṃ—
dn24:1.13.16.eng: That naked ascetic Kaḷāramaṭṭaka, who you imagine to be a true holy man,

dn24:1.13.17.pli: sādhurūpo ayaṃ samaṇoti, so nacirasseva parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṃ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālaṃ karissatī’ti.
dn24:1.13.17.eng: will shortly be clothed, living with a partner, eating rice and porridge, having gone past all the shrines near Vesālī. And he will die after losing all his fame.’

dn24:1.13.18.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako nacirasseva parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṃ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālamakāsi.

dn24:1.14.2.pli: ‘acelo kira kaḷāramaṭṭako parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṃ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālaṅkato’ti.

dn24:1.14.3.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhaggava, sunakkhattaṃ licchaviputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn24:1.14.3.eng: He came to me, bowed, and sat down to one side. I said to him,

dn24:1.14.5.pli: yatheva te ahaṃ acelaṃ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṃ ārabbha byākāsiṃ, tatheva taṃ vipākaṃ, aññathā vā’ti?
dn24:1.14.5.eng: Did the declaration I made about Kaḷāramaṭṭaka turn out to be correct, or not?’

dn24:1.14.6.pli: ‘Yatheva me, bhante, bhagavā acelaṃ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṃ ārabbha byākāsi, tatheva taṃ vipākaṃ, no aññathā’ti.

dn24:1.14.8.pli: yadi evaṃ sante kataṃ vā hoti uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ akataṃ vā’ti?
dn24:1.14.8.eng: If that is so, has a superhuman demonstration of psychic power been performed or not?’

dn24:1.14.9.pli: ‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante kataṃ hoti uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ, no akatan’ti.
dn24:1.14.9.eng: ‘Clearly, sir, a superhuman demonstration of psychic power has been performed.’

dn24:1.14.10.pli: ‘Evampi kho maṃ tvaṃ, moghapurisa, uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karontaṃ evaṃ vadesi:
dn24:1.14.10.eng: ‘Though I perform such a superhuman demonstration of psychic power you say this:

dn24:1.14.11.pli: “na hi pana me, bhante, bhagavā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karotī”ti.
dn24:1.14.11.eng: “But sir, the Buddha never performs any superhuman demonstrations of psychic power for me.”

dn24:1.14.12.pli: Passa, moghapurisa, yāvañca te idaṃ aparaddhan’ti.
dn24:1.14.12.eng: See how far you have strayed!’

dn24:1.14.13.pli: Evampi kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto mayā vuccamāno apakkameva imasmā dhammavinayā, yathā taṃ āpāyiko nerayiko.
dn24:1.14.13.eng: Though I spoke to Sunakkhatta like this, he still left this teaching and training, like someone on the highway to hell.

dn24:1.15.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, bhaggava, samayaṃ tattheva vesāliyaṃ viharāmi mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
dn24:1.15.1.eng: This one time, Bhaggava, I was staying right there near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

dn24:1.15.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena acelo pāthikaputto vesāliyaṃ paṭivasati lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme.
dn24:1.15.2.eng: Now at that time the naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta was residing in Vesālī. And in the Vajjian capital he had reached the peak of material things and fame.
dn24:1.15.2.comm: The Burmese reading pāthikaputta means “son of a traveler”. However the commentary says Pāṭika (or Pāthika) was the name of his father.

dn24:1.15.3.pli: So vesāliyaṃ parisati evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati:
dn24:1.15.3.eng: He was telling a crowd in Vesālī:

dn24:1.15.4.eng: ‘Both the ascetic Gotama and I speak from knowledge.
dn24:1.15.4.comm: For ñāṇavādo (“one who speaks from knowledge”) see AN 9.38:3.3, AN 10.24:2.1, MN 26:15.7.

dn24:1.15.5.pli: Ñāṇavādo kho pana ñāṇavādena arahati uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassetuṃ.
dn24:1.15.5.eng: One who speaks from knowledge ought to display a superhuman demonstration of psychic power to another who speaks from knowledge.

dn24:1.15.6.pli: Samaṇo gotamo upaḍḍhapathaṃ āgaccheyya, ahampi upaḍḍhapathaṃ gaccheyyaṃ.
dn24:1.15.6.eng: If the ascetic Gotama meets me half-way,

dn24:1.15.7.pli: Te tattha ubhopi uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ kareyyāma.
dn24:1.15.7.eng: there we should both perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power.

dn24:1.15.8.pli: Ekañce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissati, dvāhaṃ karissāmi.
dn24:1.15.8.eng: If he performs one demonstration of psychic power, I’ll perform two.

dn24:1.15.9.pli: Dve ce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyāni karissati, cattārāhaṃ karissāmi.
dn24:1.15.9.eng: If he performs two, I’ll perform four.

dn24:1.15.10.pli: Cattāri ce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyāni karissati, aṭṭhāhaṃ karissāmi.
dn24:1.15.10.eng: If he performs four, I’ll perform eight.

dn24:1.15.11.pli: Iti yāvatakaṃ yāvatakaṃ samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissati, taddiguṇaṃ taddiguṇāhaṃ karissāmī’ti.
dn24:1.15.11.eng: However many demonstrations of psychic power the ascetic Gotama performs, I’ll perform double.’

dn24:1.16.1.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto maṃ etadavoca:
dn24:1.16.1.eng: Then Sunakkhatta came to me, bowed, sat down to one side, and told me of all this.

dn24:1.16.2.pli: ‘acelo, bhante, pāthikaputto vesāliyaṃ paṭivasati lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme.

dn24:1.16.3.pli: So vesāliyaṃ parisati evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati:

dn24:1.16.5.pli: Ñāṇavādo kho pana ñāṇavādena arahati uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassetuṃ.

dn24:1.16.6.pli: Samaṇo gotamo upaḍḍhapathaṃ āgaccheyya, ahampi upaḍḍhapathaṃ gaccheyyaṃ.

dn24:1.16.7.pli: Te tattha ubhopi uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ kareyyāma.

dn24:1.16.8.pli: Ekañce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissati, dvāhaṃ karissāmi.

dn24:1.16.9.pli: Dve ce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyāni karissati, cattārāhaṃ karissāmi.

dn24:1.16.10.pli: Cattāri ce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyāni karissati, aṭṭhāhaṃ karissāmi.

dn24:1.16.11.pli: Iti yāvatakaṃ yāvatakaṃ samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissati, taddiguṇaṃ taddiguṇāhaṃ karissāmī”’ti.

dn24:1.16.12.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhaggava, sunakkhattaṃ licchaviputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:

dn24:1.16.13.pli: ‘abhabbo kho, sunakkhatta, acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.
dn24:1.16.13.eng: ‘Sunakkhatta, the naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta is not capable of meeting me face to face, unless he gives up that statement and that intention, and lets go of that view.

dn24:1.16.15.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyā’ti.
dn24:1.16.15.eng: meet me face to face without giving up those things, his head may explode.’

dn24:1.17.1.pli: ‘Rakkhatetaṃ, bhante, bhagavā vācaṃ, rakkhatetaṃ sugato vācan’ti.
dn24:1.17.1.eng: ‘Careful what you say, Blessed One! Careful what you say, Holy One!’

dn24:1.17.2.pli: ‘Kiṃ pana maṃ tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, evaṃ vadesi—
dn24:1.17.2.eng: ‘But why do you say this to me, Sunakkhatta?’

dn24:1.17.3.pli: rakkhatetaṃ, bhante, bhagavā vācaṃ, rakkhatetaṃ sugato vācan’ti?

dn24:1.17.4.pli: ‘Bhagavatā cassa, bhante, esā vācā ekaṃsena odhāritā—
dn24:1.17.4.eng: ‘Sir, the Buddha has categorically asserted that

dn24:1.17.5.pli: abhabbo acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.
dn24:1.17.5.eng: Pāṭikaputta is not capable of meeting the Buddha face to face, otherwise

dn24:1.17.7.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti.

dn24:1.17.8.pli: Acelo ca, bhante, pāthikaputto virūparūpena bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṃ āgaccheyya, tadassa bhagavato musā’ti.
dn24:1.17.8.eng: But Pāṭikaputta might meet the Buddha face to face in disguise, proving the Buddha wrong.’

dn24:1.18.1.pli: ‘Api nu, sunakkhatta, tathāgato taṃ vācaṃ bhāseyya yā sā vācā dvayagāminī’ti?
dn24:1.18.1.eng: ‘Sunakkhatta, would the Realized One make an ambiguous statement?’

dn24:1.18.2.pli: ‘Kiṃ pana, bhante, bhagavatā acelo pāthikaputto cetasā ceto paricca vidito—
dn24:1.18.2.eng: ‘But sir, did you make that statement after encompassing Pāṭikaputta’s mind with your mind?

dn24:1.18.3.pli: abhabbo acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.

dn24:1.18.5.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti?

dn24:1.18.6.eng: Or did deities tell you about it?’

dn24:1.18.7.pli: abhabbo, bhante, acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.

dn24:1.18.9.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyā’ti?

dn24:1.18.10.pli: ‘Cetasā ceto paricca vidito ceva me, sunakkhatta, acelo pāthikaputto—

dn24:1.18.11.pli: abhabbo acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.

dn24:1.18.13.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti.

dn24:1.18.15.pli: abhabbo, bhante, acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.

dn24:1.18.17.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti.

dn24:1.18.18.pli: Ajitopi nāma licchavīnaṃ senāpati adhunā kālaṅkato tāvatiṃsakāyaṃ upapanno.
dn24:1.18.18.eng: For Ajita the Licchavi general has recently passed away and been reborn in the host of the thirty-three.

dn24:1.18.19.eng: He came and told me this,

dn24:1.18.20.eng: “The naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta is shameless, sir,

dn24:1.18.22.pli: Mampi, bhante, acelo pāthikaputto byākāsi vajjigāme—
dn24:1.18.22.eng: For he has declared of me in the Vajjian capital:

dn24:1.18.23.eng: ‘Ajita the Licchavi general has been reborn in the Great Hell.’

dn24:1.18.24.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ, bhante, mahānirayaṃ upapanno;

dn24:1.18.25.eng: I have been reborn in the host of the thirty-three.

dn24:1.18.26.eng: The naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta is shameless, sir,

dn24:1.18.28.pli: abhabbo ca, bhante, acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.
dn24:1.18.28.eng: Pāṭikaputta is not capable of meeting the Buddha face to face, otherwise

dn24:1.18.30.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti.

dn24:1.18.31.pli: Iti kho, sunakkhatta, cetasā ceto paricca vidito ceva me acelo pāthikaputto abhabbo acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.
dn24:1.18.31.eng: Thus I both made that statement after encompassing Pāṭikaputta’s mind with my mind,

dn24:1.18.33.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti.

dn24:1.18.34.eng: and deities told me about it.

dn24:1.18.35.pli: abhabbo, bhante, acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.

dn24:1.18.37.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti.

dn24:1.18.38.pli: So kho panāhaṃ, sunakkhatta, vesāliyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena acelassa pāthikaputtassa ārāmo tenupasaṅkamissāmi divāvihārāya.
dn24:1.18.38.eng: So Sunakkhatta, I’ll wander for alms in Vesālī. After the meal, on my return from almsround, I’ll go to Pāṭikaputta’s monastery for the day’s meditation.

dn24:1.18.39.pli: Yassadāni tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, icchasi, tassa ārocehī’ti.
dn24:1.18.39.eng: Now you may tell him, if you so wish.’

dn24:1.19.1.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhaggava, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ.
dn24:1.19.1.eng: Then, Bhaggava, I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.

dn24:1.19.2.pli: Vesāliyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena acelassa pāthikaputtassa ārāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃ divāvihārāya.
dn24:1.19.2.eng: After the meal, on my return from almsround, I went to Pāṭikaputta’s monastery for the day’s meditation.

dn24:1.19.3.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto taramānarūpo vesāliṃ pavisitvā yena abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā abhiññāte abhiññāte licchavī etadavoca:
dn24:1.19.3.eng: Then Sunakkhatta rushed into Vesālī to see the very well-known Licchavis and said to them,

dn24:1.19.4.pli: ‘esāvuso, bhagavā vesāliyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena acelassa pāthikaputtassa ārāmo tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
dn24:1.19.4.eng: ‘Good sirs, after his almsround, the Buddha has gone to Pāṭikaputta’s monastery for the day’s meditation.

dn24:1.19.5.pli: Abhikkamathāyasmanto abhikkamathāyasmanto, sādhurūpānaṃ samaṇānaṃ uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
dn24:1.19.5.eng: Come forth, good sirs, come forth! There will be a superhuman demonstration of psychic power by the holy ascetics!’

dn24:1.19.6.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, abhiññātānaṃ abhiññātānaṃ licchavīnaṃ etadahosi:
dn24:1.19.6.eng: So the very well-known Licchavis thought,

dn24:1.19.7.pli: ‘sādhurūpānaṃ kira, bho, samaṇānaṃ uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ bhavissati;
dn24:1.19.7.eng: ‘It seems there will be a superhuman demonstration of psychic power by the holy ascetics!

dn24:1.19.9.pli: Yena ca abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatinecayikā nānātitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā tenupasaṅkami. upasaṅkamitvā abhiññāte abhiññāte nānātitthiye samaṇabrāhmaṇe etadavoca:
dn24:1.19.9.eng: Then he went to see the very well-known well-to-do brahmins, rich householders, and ascetics and brahmins who follow various other religions, and said the same thing.

dn24:1.19.10.pli: ‘esāvuso, bhagavā vesāliyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena acelassa pāthikaputtassa ārāmo tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.

dn24:1.19.11.pli: Abhikkamathāyasmanto abhikkamathāyasmanto, sādhurūpānaṃ samaṇānaṃ uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ bhavissatī’ti.

dn24:1.19.12.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, abhiññātānaṃ abhiññātānaṃ nānātitthiyānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ etadahosi:

dn24:1.19.13.pli: ‘sādhurūpānaṃ kira, bho, samaṇānaṃ uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ bhavissati;
dn24:1.19.13.eng: ‘It seems there will be a superhuman demonstration of psychic power by the holy ascetics!

dn24:1.19.15.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī, abhiññātā abhiññātā ca brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatinecayikā nānātitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā yena acelassa pāthikaputtassa ārāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
dn24:1.19.15.eng: Then all those very well-known people went to Pāṭikaputta’s monastery.

dn24:1.19.16.pli: Sā esā, bhaggava, parisā mahā hoti anekasatā anekasahassā.
dn24:1.19.16.eng: That assembly was large, Bhaggava; there were many hundreds, many thousands of them.

dn24:1.20.2.pli: ‘abhikkantā kira abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī, abhikkantā abhiññātā abhiññātā ca brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatinecayikā nānātitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā.
dn24:1.20.2.eng: ‘It seems that very well-known Licchavis, well-to-do brahmins, rich householders, and ascetics and brahmins who follow various other religions have come forth.

dn24:1.20.3.pli: Samaṇopi gotamo mayhaṃ ārāme divāvihāraṃ nisinno’ti.
dn24:1.20.3.eng: And the ascetic Gotama is sitting in my monastery for the day’s meditation.’

dn24:1.20.4.eng: When he heard that, he became frightened, scared, his hair standing on end.

dn24:1.20.5.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, acelo pāthikaputto bhīto saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto yena tindukakhāṇuparibbājakārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
dn24:1.20.5.eng: In fear he went to the Pale-Moon Ebony Trunk Monastery of the wanderers.

dn24:1.20.7.pli: ‘acelo kira pāthikaputto bhīto saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto yena tindukakhāṇuparibbājakārāmo tenupasaṅkanto’ti.

dn24:1.20.8.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sā parisā aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:

dn24:1.20.9.pli: ‘Ehi tvaṃ, bho purisa, yena tindukakhāṇuparibbājakārāmo, yena acelo pāthikaputto tenupasaṅkama. upasaṅkamitvā acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ evaṃ vadehi:
dn24:1.20.9.eng: ‘Come, my man, go to see Pāṭikaputta at the Pale-Moon Ebony Trunk Monastery and say to him,

dn24:1.20.10.pli: “abhikkamāvuso, pāthikaputta, abhikkantā abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī, abhikkantā abhiññātā abhiññātā ca brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatinecayikā nānātitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā, samaṇopi gotamo āyasmato ārāme divāvihāraṃ nisinno;
dn24:1.20.10.eng: “Come forth, Reverend Pāṭikaputta! All these very well-known people have come forth, and the ascetic Gotama is sitting in your monastery for the day’s meditation.

dn24:1.20.11.pli: bhāsitā kho pana te esā, āvuso pāthikaputta, vesāliyaṃ parisati vācā
dn24:1.20.11.eng: For you stated this in the assembly at Vesālī:

dn24:1.20.12.eng: ‘Both the ascetic Gotama and I speak from knowledge.

dn24:1.20.13.pli: Ñāṇavādo kho pana ñāṇavādena arahati uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassetuṃ.
dn24:1.20.13.eng: One who speaks from knowledge ought to display a superhuman demonstration of psychic power to another who speaks from knowledge.

dn24:1.20.14.pli: Samaṇo gotamo upaḍḍhapathaṃ āgaccheyya ahampi upaḍḍhapathaṃ gaccheyyaṃ.
dn24:1.20.14.eng: If the ascetic Gotama meets me half-way,

dn24:1.20.15.pli: Te tattha ubhopi uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ kareyyāma.
dn24:1.20.15.eng: there we should both perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power.

dn24:1.20.16.pli: Ekañce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissati, dvāhaṃ karissāmi.
dn24:1.20.16.eng: If he performs one demonstration of psychic power, I’ll perform two.

dn24:1.20.17.pli: Dve ce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyāni karissati, cattārāhaṃ karissāmi.
dn24:1.20.17.eng: If he performs two, I’ll perform four.

dn24:1.20.18.pli: Cattāri ce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyāni karissati, aṭṭhāhaṃ karissāmi.
dn24:1.20.18.eng: If he performs four, I’ll perform eight.

dn24:1.20.19.pli: Iti yāvatakaṃ yāvatakaṃ samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karissati, taddiguṇaṃ taddiguṇāhaṃ karissāmī”ti
dn24:1.20.19.eng: However many demonstrations of psychic power the ascetic Gotama performs, I’ll perform double.’

dn24:1.20.21.pli: Sabbapaṭhamaṃyeva āgantvā samaṇo gotamo āyasmato ārāme divāvihāraṃ nisinno’ti.
dn24:1.20.21.eng: The ascetic Gotama has come the first half, and is sitting in your monastery.”’

dn24:1.21.1.pli: Evaṃ, bhoti kho, bhaggava, so puriso tassā parisāya paṭissutvā yena tindukakhāṇuparibbājakārāmo, yena acelo pāthikaputto tenupasaṅkami. upasaṅkamitvā acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn24:1.21.1.eng: ‘Yes, worthy sir,’ replied that man, and delivered the message.

dn24:1.21.2.pli: ‘abhikkamāvuso pāthikaputta, abhikkantā abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī, abhikkantā abhiññātā abhiññātā ca brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatinecayikā nānātitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā.

dn24:1.21.3.pli: Samaṇopi gotamo āyasmato ārāme divāvihāraṃ nisinno.

dn24:1.21.4.pli: Bhāsitā kho pana te esā, āvuso pāthikaputta, vesāliyaṃ parisati vācā—

dn24:1.21.6.pli: Ñāṇavādo kho pana ñāṇavādena arahati uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassetuṃ …pe…

dn24:1.21.9.pli: Sabbapaṭhamaṃyeva āgantvā samaṇo gotamo āyasmato ārāme divāvihāraṃ nisinno’ti.

dn24:1.21.10.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhaggava, acelo pāthikaputto ‘āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvuso’ti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātuṃ.
dn24:1.21.10.eng: When he had spoken, Pāṭikaputta said: ‘I’m coming, good sir, I’m coming!’ But wriggle as he might, he couldn’t get up from his seat.

dn24:1.21.11.pli: Atha kho so, bhaggava, puriso acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn24:1.21.11.eng: Then that man said to Pāṭikaputta,

dn24:1.21.12.pli: ‘kiṃ su nāma te, āvuso pāthikaputta, pāvaḷā su nāma te pīṭhakasmiṃ allīnā, pīṭhakaṃ su nāma te pāvaḷāsu allīnaṃ?
dn24:1.21.12.eng: ‘What’s up, Reverend Pāṭikaputta? Is your bottom stuck to the bench, or is the bench stuck to your bottom?

dn24:1.21.13.pli: Āyāmi āvuso, āyāmi āvusoti vatvā tattheva saṃsappasi, na sakkosi āsanāpi vuṭṭhātun’ti.
dn24:1.21.13.eng: You say “I’m coming, good sir, I’m coming!” But wriggle as you might, you can’t get up from your seat.’

dn24:1.21.14.pli: Evampi kho, bhaggava, vuccamāno acelo pāthikaputto ‘āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvuso’ti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātuṃ.
dn24:1.21.14.eng: And as he was speaking, Pāṭikaputta said: ‘I’m coming, good sir, I’m coming!’ But wriggle as he might, he couldn’t get up from his seat.

dn24:1.22.1.pli: Yadā kho so, bhaggava, puriso aññāsi:

dn24:1.22.3.pli: Āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvusoti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātun’ti.

dn24:1.22.4.eng: he returned to the assembly and said,

dn24:1.22.6.pli: Āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvusoti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātun’ti.
dn24:1.22.6.eng: He says “I’m coming, good sir, I’m coming!” But wriggle as he might, he can’t get up from his seat.’

dn24:1.22.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhaggava, taṃ parisaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn24:1.22.7.eng: When he said this, I said to the assembly,

dn24:1.22.8.pli: ‘abhabbo kho, āvuso, acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.
dn24:1.22.8.eng: ‘The naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta is not capable of meeting me face to face, unless he gives up that statement and that intention, and lets go of that view.

dn24:1.22.10.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyā’ti.
dn24:1.22.10.eng: meet me face to face without giving up those things, his head may explode.’

dn24:1.22.11.eng: The first recitation section is finished.

dn24:2.1.1.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, aññataro licchavimahāmatto uṭṭhāyāsanā taṃ parisaṃ etadavoca:
dn24:2.1.1.eng: Then, Bhaggava, a certain Licchavi minister stood up and said to the assembly,

dn24:2.1.2.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, muhuttaṃ tāva āgametha, yāvāhaṃ gacchāmi.
dn24:2.1.2.eng: ‘Well then, worthies, wait an hour, I’ll go.

dn24:2.1.3.pli: Appeva nāma ahampi sakkuṇeyyaṃ acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ imaṃ parisaṃ ānetun’ti.
dn24:2.1.3.eng: Hopefully I’ll be able to lead Pāṭikaputta back to the assembly.’

dn24:2.1.4.pli: Atha kho so, bhaggava, licchavimahāmatto yena tindukakhāṇuparibbājakārāmo, yena acelo pāthikaputto tenupasaṅkami. upasaṅkamitvā acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn24:2.1.4.eng: So that minister went to see Pāṭikaputta and said,

dn24:2.1.5.pli: ‘abhikkamāvuso pāthikaputta, abhikkantaṃ te seyyo, abhikkantā abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī, abhikkantā abhiññātā abhiññātā ca brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatinecayikā nānātitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā. Samaṇopi gotamo āyasmato ārāme divāvihāraṃ nisinno.
dn24:2.1.5.eng: ‘Come forth, Reverend Pāṭikaputta! It’s best for you to come forth. All these very well-known people have come forth, and the ascetic Gotama is sitting in your monastery for the day’s meditation.

dn24:2.1.6.pli: Bhāsitā kho pana te esā, āvuso pāthikaputta, vesāliyaṃ parisati vācā—
dn24:2.1.6.eng: You said you’d meet the ascetic Gotama half-way.

dn24:2.1.10.pli: Sabbapaṭhamaṃyeva āgantvā samaṇo gotamo āyasmato ārāme divāvihāraṃ nisinno.
dn24:2.1.10.eng: The ascetic Gotama has come the first half, and is sitting in your monastery.

dn24:2.1.11.pli: Bhāsitā kho panesā, āvuso pāthikaputta, samaṇena gotamena parisati vācā—
dn24:2.1.11.eng: The ascetic Gotama has told the assembly

dn24:2.1.12.pli: abhabbo kho acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.
dn24:2.1.12.eng: that you’re not capable of meeting him face to face.

dn24:2.1.14.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti.

dn24:2.1.15.pli: Abhikkamāvuso pāthikaputta, abhikkamaneneva te jayaṃ karissāma, samaṇassa gotamassa parājayan’ti.
dn24:2.1.15.eng: Come forth, Pāṭikaputta! When you come forth we’ll make you win and the ascetic Gotama lose.’

dn24:2.2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhaggava, acelo pāthikaputto ‘āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvuso’ti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātuṃ.
dn24:2.2.1.eng: When he had spoken, Pāṭikaputta said: ‘I’m coming, good sir, I’m coming!’ But wriggle as he might, he couldn’t get up from his seat.

dn24:2.2.2.pli: Atha kho so, bhaggava, licchavimahāmatto acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn24:2.2.2.eng: Then the minister said to Pāṭikaputta,

dn24:2.2.3.pli: ‘kiṃ su nāma te, āvuso pāthikaputta, pāvaḷā su nāma te pīṭhakasmiṃ allīnā, pīṭhakaṃ su nāma te pāvaḷāsu allīnaṃ?
dn24:2.2.3.eng: ‘What’s up, Reverend Pāṭikaputta? Is your bottom stuck to the bench, or is the bench stuck to your bottom?

dn24:2.2.4.pli: Āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvusoti vatvā tattheva saṃsappasi, na sakkosi āsanāpi vuṭṭhātun’ti.
dn24:2.2.4.eng: You say “I’m coming, good sir, I’m coming!” But wriggle as you might, you can’t get up from your seat.’

dn24:2.2.5.pli: Evampi kho, bhaggava, vuccamāno acelo pāthikaputto ‘āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvuso’ti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātuṃ.
dn24:2.2.5.eng: And as he was speaking, Pāṭikaputta said: ‘I’m coming, good sir, I’m coming!’ But wriggle as he might, he couldn’t get up from his seat.

dn24:2.3.1.pli: Yadā kho so, bhaggava, licchavimahāmatto aññāsi:

dn24:2.3.2.pli: ‘parābhūtarūpo ayaṃ acelo pāthikaputto āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvusoti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātun’ti.

dn24:2.3.3.eng: he returned to the assembly and said,

dn24:2.3.4.pli: ‘parābhūtarūpo, bho, acelo pāthikaputto āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvusoti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātun’ti.

dn24:2.3.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhaggava, taṃ parisaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn24:2.3.5.eng: When he said this, I said to the assembly,

dn24:2.3.6.pli: ‘abhabbo kho, āvuso, acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.
dn24:2.3.6.eng: ‘Pāṭikaputta is not capable of meeting me face to face, otherwise

dn24:2.3.8.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyya.

dn24:2.3.9.eng: Even if the good Licchavis were to think,

dn24:2.3.10.pli: mayaṃ acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ varattāhi bandhitvā goyugehi āviñcheyyāmāti, tā varattā chijjeyyuṃ pāthikaputto vā.
dn24:2.3.10.eng: “Let’s bind Pāṭikaputta with straps and drag him with a pair of oxen!” But either the straps will break or Pāṭikaputta will.’

dn24:2.3.11.pli: Abhabbo pana acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.

dn24:2.3.13.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyā’ti.

dn24:2.4.1.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, jāliyo dārupattikantevāsī uṭṭhāyāsanā taṃ parisaṃ etadavoca:
dn24:2.4.1.eng: Then, Bhaggava, Jāliya, the pupil of the wood-bowl ascetic, stood up and said to the assembly,

dn24:2.4.2.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, muhuttaṃ tāva āgametha, yāvāhaṃ gacchāmi;
dn24:2.4.2.eng: ‘Well then, worthies, wait an hour, I’ll go.

dn24:2.4.3.pli: appeva nāma ahampi sakkuṇeyyaṃ acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ imaṃ parisaṃ ānetun’ti.
dn24:2.4.3.eng: Hopefully I’ll be able to lead Pāṭikaputta back to the assembly.’

dn24:2.4.4.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, jāliyo dārupattikantevāsī yena tindukakhāṇuparibbājakārāmo, yena acelo pāthikaputto tenupasaṅkami. upasaṅkamitvā acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn24:2.4.4.eng: So Jāliya went to see Pāṭikaputta and said,

dn24:2.4.5.pli: ‘abhikkamāvuso pāthikaputta, abhikkantaṃ te seyyo. Abhikkantā abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī, abhikkantā abhiññātā abhiññātā ca brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatinecayikā nānātitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā. Samaṇopi gotamo āyasmato ārāme divāvihāraṃ nisinno.
dn24:2.4.5.eng: ‘Come forth, Reverend Pāṭikaputta! It’s best for you to come forth. All these very well-known people have come forth, and the ascetic Gotama is sitting in your monastery for the day’s meditation.

dn24:2.4.6.pli: Bhāsitā kho pana te esā, āvuso pāthikaputta, vesāliyaṃ parisati vācā—
dn24:2.4.6.eng: You said you’d meet the ascetic Gotama half-way.

dn24:2.4.10.pli: Sabbapaṭhamaṃyeva āgantvā samaṇo gotamo āyasmato ārāme divāvihāraṃ nisinno.
dn24:2.4.10.eng: The ascetic Gotama has come the first half, and is sitting in your monastery.

dn24:2.4.11.pli: Bhāsitā kho panesā, āvuso pāthikaputta, samaṇena gotamena parisati vācā—
dn24:2.4.11.eng: The ascetic Gotama has told the assembly

dn24:2.4.12.pli: abhabbo acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.
dn24:2.4.12.eng: that you’re not capable of meeting him face to face.

dn24:2.4.14.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyya.

dn24:2.4.15.eng: And he said that even if the Licchavis

dn24:2.4.16.pli: mayaṃ acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ varattāhi bandhitvā goyugehi āviñcheyyāmāti. Tā varattā chijjeyyuṃ pāthikaputto vā.
dn24:2.4.16.eng: try to bind you with straps and drag you with a pair of oxen, either the straps will break or you will.

dn24:2.4.17.pli: Abhabbo pana acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.

dn24:2.4.19.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ āgaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti.

dn24:2.4.20.pli: Abhikkamāvuso pāthikaputta, abhikkamaneneva te jayaṃ karissāma, samaṇassa gotamassa parājayan’ti.
dn24:2.4.20.eng: Come forth, Pāṭikaputta! When you come forth we’ll make you win and the ascetic Gotama lose.’

dn24:2.5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhaggava, acelo pāthikaputto ‘āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvuso’ti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātuṃ.
dn24:2.5.1.eng: When he had spoken, Pāṭikaputta said: ‘I’m coming, good sir, I’m coming!’ But wriggle as he might, he couldn’t get up from his seat.

dn24:2.5.2.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, jāliyo dārupattikantevāsī acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ etadavoca:

dn24:2.5.3.pli: ‘kiṃ su nāma te, āvuso pāthikaputta, pāvaḷā su nāma te pīṭhakasmiṃ allīnā, pīṭhakaṃ su nāma te pāvaḷāsu allīnaṃ?
dn24:2.5.3.eng: ‘What’s up, Reverend Pāṭikaputta? Is your bottom stuck to the bench, or is the bench stuck to your bottom?

dn24:2.5.4.pli: Āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvusoti vatvā tattheva saṃsappasi, na sakkosi āsanāpi vuṭṭhātun’ti.
dn24:2.5.4.eng: You say “I’m coming, good sir, I’m coming!” But wriggle as you might, you can’t get up from your seat.’

dn24:2.5.5.pli: Evampi kho, bhaggava, vuccamāno acelo pāthikaputto ‘āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvuso’ti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātunti.
dn24:2.5.5.eng: And as he was speaking, Pāṭikaputta said: ‘I’m coming, good sir, I’m coming!’ But wriggle as he might, he couldn’t get up from his seat.

dn24:2.6.1.pli: Yadā kho, bhaggava, jāliyo dārupattikantevāsī aññāsi:

dn24:2.6.2.pli: ‘parābhūtarūpo ayaṃ acelo pāthikaputto āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvusoti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātun’ti, atha naṃ etadavoca—
dn24:2.6.2.eng: that Pāṭikaputta had lost, he said to him,

dn24:2.6.3.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, āvuso pāthikaputta, sīhassa migarañño etadahosi:
dn24:2.6.3.eng: ‘Once upon a time, Reverend Pāṭikaputta, it occurred to a lion, king of beasts,

dn24:2.6.4.eng: “Why don’t I make my lair near a certain forest?

dn24:2.6.5.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā sāyanhasamayaṃ āsayā nikkhameyyaṃ, āsayā nikkhamitvā vijambheyyaṃ, vijambhitvā samantā catuddisā anuvilokeyyaṃ, samantā catuddisā anuviloketvā tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ nadeyyaṃ, tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ naditvā gocarāya pakkameyyaṃ.
dn24:2.6.5.eng: Towards evening I can emerge from my den, yawn, survey the four quarters, roar my lion’s roar three times, and set out on the hunt.

dn24:2.6.6.pli: So varaṃ varaṃ migasaṅghe vadhitvā mudumaṃsāni mudumaṃsāni bhakkhayitvā tameva āsayaṃ ajjhupeyyan’ti.
dn24:2.6.6.eng: Having slain the very best of the deer herd, and eaten the most tender flesh, I could return to my den.”

dn24:2.6.7.pli: Atha kho, āvuso, so sīho migarājā aññataraṃ vanasaṇḍaṃ nissāya āsayaṃ kappesi.
dn24:2.6.7.eng: And so that’s what he did.

dn24:2.6.8.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā sāyanhasamayaṃ āsayā nikkhami, āsayā nikkhamitvā vijambhi, vijambhitvā samantā catuddisā anuvilokesi, samantā catuddisā anuviloketvā tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ nadi, tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ naditvā gocarāya pakkāmi.

dn24:2.6.9.pli: So varaṃ varaṃ migasaṅghe vadhitvā mudumaṃsāni mudumaṃsāni bhakkhayitvā tameva āsayaṃ ajjhupesi.

dn24:2.6.10.pli: Tasseva kho, āvuso pāthikaputta, sīhassa migarañño vighāsasaṃvaḍḍho jarasiṅgālo ditto ceva balavā ca.
dn24:2.6.10.eng: Now, there was an old jackal who had grown fat on the lion’s leavings, becoming arrogant and strong.

dn24:2.6.11.pli: Atha kho, āvuso, tassa jarasiṅgālassa etadahosi:

dn24:2.6.12.eng: “What does the lion, king of beasts, have that I don’t?

dn24:2.6.13.pli: Yannūnāhampi aññataraṃ vanasaṇḍaṃ nissāya āsayaṃ kappeyyaṃ.
dn24:2.6.13.eng: Why don’t I also make my lair near a certain forest?

dn24:2.6.14.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā sāyanhasamayaṃ āsayā nikkhameyyaṃ, āsayā nikkhamitvā vijambheyyaṃ, vijambhitvā samantā catuddisā anuvilokeyyaṃ, samantā catuddisā anuviloketvā tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ nadeyyaṃ, tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ naditvā gocarāya pakkameyyaṃ.
dn24:2.6.14.eng: Towards evening I can emerge from my den, yawn, survey the four quarters, roar my lion’s roar three times, and set out on the hunt.

dn24:2.6.15.pli: So varaṃ varaṃ migasaṅghe vadhitvā mudumaṃsāni mudumaṃsāni bhakkhayitvā tameva āsayaṃ ajjhupeyyan’ti.
dn24:2.6.15.eng: Having slain the very best of the deer herd, and eaten the most tender flesh, I could return to my den.”

dn24:2.7.1.pli: Atha kho so, āvuso, jarasiṅgālo aññataraṃ vanasaṇḍaṃ nissāya āsayaṃ kappesi.
dn24:2.7.1.eng: And so that’s what he did.

dn24:2.7.2.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā sāyanhasamayaṃ āsayā nikkhami, āsayā nikkhamitvā vijambhi, vijambhitvā samantā catuddisā anuvilokesi, samantā catuddisā anuviloketvā tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ nadissāmīti siṅgālakaṃyeva anadi bheraṇḍakaṃyeva anadi, ke ca chave siṅgāle, ke pana sīhanādeti.
dn24:2.7.2.eng: But when he tried to roar a lion’s roar, he only managed to squeal and yelp like a jackal. And what is a pathetic jackal’s squeal next to the roar of a lion?

dn24:2.7.3.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, āvuso pāthikaputta, sugatāpadānesu jīvamāno sugatātirittāni bhuñjamāno tathāgate arahante sammāsambuddhe āsādetabbaṃ maññasi.
dn24:2.7.3.eng: In the same way, reverend, while living off the leavings of the Holy One, enjoying the leftovers of the Holy One, you presume to attack the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
dn24:2.7.3.comm: Apadāna means “what has been left over, leavings, traces”.

dn24:2.7.4.pli: Ke ca chave pāthikaputte, kā ca tathāgatānaṃ arahantānaṃ sammāsambuddhānaṃ āsādanāti.
dn24:2.7.4.eng: Who are the pathetic Pāṭikaputtas to attack the Realized Ones, the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas?’

dn24:2.8.1.pli: Yato kho, bhaggava, jāliyo dārupattikantevāsī iminā opammena neva asakkhi acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ tamhā āsanā cāvetuṃ.
dn24:2.8.1.eng: When Jāliya couldn’t get Pāṭikaputta to shift from his seat even with this simile,

dn24:2.8.3.eng: ‘Seeing himself as equal to the lion,

dn24:2.8.4.eng: the jackal presumed “I’m the king of the beasts!”

dn24:2.8.5.eng: But he actually only managed to yelp,

dn24:2.8.6.pli: Ke ca chave siṅgāle ke pana sīhanādeti.
dn24:2.8.6.eng: and what’s a sad jackal’s squeal to the roar of a lion?

dn24:2.8.7.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, āvuso pāthikaputta, sugatāpadānesu jīvamāno sugatātirittāni bhuñjamāno tathāgate arahante sammāsambuddhe āsādetabbaṃ maññasi.
dn24:2.8.7.eng: In the same way, reverend, while living off the leavings of the Holy One, you presume to attack him!’

dn24:2.8.8.pli: Ke ca chave pāthikaputte, kā ca tathāgatānaṃ arahantānaṃ sammāsambuddhānaṃ āsādanā’ti.

dn24:2.9.1.pli: Yato kho, bhaggava, jāliyo dārupattikantevāsī imināpi opammena neva asakkhi acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ tamhā āsanā cāvetuṃ.
dn24:2.9.1.eng: When Jāliya couldn’t get Pāṭikaputta to shift from his seat even with this simile,

dn24:2.9.4.eng: seeing himself grown fat on scraps,

dn24:2.9.5.eng: until he doesn’t even see himself,

dn24:2.9.6.eng: the jackal presumes he’s a tiger.

dn24:2.9.7.eng: But he actually only managed to yelp,

dn24:2.9.8.pli: Ke ca chave siṅgāle ke pana sīhanādeti.
dn24:2.9.8.eng: and what’s a sad jackal’s squeal to the roar of a lion?

dn24:2.9.9.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, āvuso pāthikaputta, sugatāpadānesu jīvamāno sugatātirittāni bhuñjamāno tathāgate arahante sammāsambuddhe āsādetabbaṃ maññasi.
dn24:2.9.9.eng: In the same way, reverend, while living off the leavings of the Holy One, you presume to attack him!’

dn24:2.9.10.pli: Ke ca chave pāthikaputte, kā ca tathāgatānaṃ arahantānaṃ sammāsambuddhānaṃ āsādanā’ti.

dn24:2.10.1.pli: Yato kho, bhaggava, jāliyo dārupattikantevāsī imināpi opammena neva asakkhi acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ tamhā āsanā cāvetuṃ.
dn24:2.10.1.eng: When Jāliya couldn’t get Pāṭikaputta to shift from his seat even with this simile,

dn24:2.10.3.eng: ‘Gorged on frogs, and mice from the barn,

dn24:2.10.4.eng: and carcasses tossed in the cemetery,

dn24:2.10.5.eng: thriving in the great, empty wood,

dn24:2.10.6.eng: the jackal presumed “I’m the king of the beasts!”

dn24:2.10.7.eng: But he actually only managed to yelp,

dn24:2.10.8.pli: Ke ca chave siṅgāle ke pana sīhanādeti.
dn24:2.10.8.eng: and what’s a sad jackal’s squeal to the roar of a lion?

dn24:2.10.9.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, āvuso pāthikaputta, sugatāpadānesu jīvamāno sugatātirittāni bhuñjamāno tathāgate arahante sammāsambuddhe āsādetabbaṃ maññasi.
dn24:2.10.9.eng: In the same way, reverend, while living off the leavings of the Holy One, enjoying the leftovers of the Holy One, you presume to attack the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

dn24:2.10.10.pli: Ke ca chave pāthikaputte, kā ca tathāgatānaṃ arahantānaṃ sammāsambuddhānaṃ āsādanā’ti.
dn24:2.10.10.eng: Who are the pathetic Pāṭikaputtas to attack the Realized Ones, the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas?’

dn24:2.11.1.pli: Yato kho, bhaggava, jāliyo dārupattikantevāsī imināpi opammena neva asakkhi acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ tamhā āsanā cāvetuṃ.
dn24:2.11.1.eng: When Jāliya couldn’t get Pāṭikaputta to shift from his seat even with this simile,

dn24:2.11.2.eng: he returned to the assembly and said,

dn24:2.11.3.pli: ‘parābhūtarūpo, bho, acelo pāthikaputto āyāmi āvuso, āyāmi, āvusoti vatvā tattheva saṃsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātun’ti.
dn24:2.11.3.eng: ‘Pāṭikaputta has lost, worthies. He says “I’m coming, good sirs, I’m coming!” But wriggle as he might, he can’t get up from his seat.’

dn24:2.12.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhaggava, taṃ parisaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn24:2.12.1.eng: When he said this, I said to the assembly,

dn24:2.12.2.pli: ‘abhabbo kho, āvuso, acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.
dn24:2.12.2.eng: ‘The naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta is not capable of meeting me face to face, unless he gives up that statement and that intention, and lets go of that view.

dn24:2.12.4.pli: ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyya.
dn24:2.12.4.eng: meet me face to face without giving up those things, his head may explode.

dn24:2.12.5.eng: The good Licchavis might even think,

dn24:2.12.6.pli: mayaṃ acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ varattāhi bandhitvā nāgehi āviñcheyyāmāti. Tā varattā chijjeyyuṃ pāthikaputto vā.
dn24:2.12.6.eng: “Let’s bind Pāṭikaputta with straps and drag him with a pair of oxen!” But either the straps will break or Pāṭikaputta will.

dn24:2.12.7.pli: Abhabbo pana acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ.
dn24:2.12.7.eng: Pāṭikaputta is not capable of meeting me face to face, otherwise

dn24:2.12.8.pli: Sacepissa evamassa—ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyā’ti.

dn24:2.13.1.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhaggava, taṃ parisaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesiṃ samādapesiṃ samuttejesiṃ sampahaṃsesiṃ, taṃ parisaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā mahābandhanā mokkhaṃ karitvā caturāsītipāṇasahassāni mahāviduggā uddharitvā tejodhātuṃ samāpajjitvā sattatālaṃ vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā aññaṃ sattatālampi acciṃ abhinimminitvā pajjalitvā dhūmāyitvā mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ paccuṭṭhāsiṃ.
dn24:2.13.1.eng: Then, Bhaggava, I educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired that assembly with a Dhamma talk. I released that assembly from the great bondage, and lifted 84,000 beings from the great swamp. Next I entered upon the fire element, rose into the air to the height of seven palm trees, and created a flame another seven palm trees high, blazing and smoking. Finally I landed at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
dn24:2.13.1.comm: This kind of elaborate display is commonly depicted in late texts, but is not otherwise found in early Pali.

dn24:2.13.2.pli: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhaggava, sunakkhattaṃ licchaviputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn24:2.13.2.eng: Then Sunakkhatta came to me, bowed, and sat down to one side. I said to him,

dn24:2.13.4.pli: yatheva te ahaṃ acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ ārabbha byākāsiṃ, tatheva taṃ vipākaṃ aññathā vā’ti?
dn24:2.13.4.eng: Did the declaration I made about Pāṭikaputta turn out to be correct, or not?’

dn24:2.13.5.pli: ‘Yatheva me, bhante, bhagavā acelaṃ pāthikaputtaṃ ārabbha byākāsi, tatheva taṃ vipākaṃ, no aññathā’ti.

dn24:2.13.7.pli: yadi evaṃ sante kataṃ vā hoti uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ, akataṃ vā’ti?
dn24:2.13.7.eng: If that is so, has a superhuman demonstration of psychic power been performed or not?’

dn24:2.13.8.pli: ‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante kataṃ hoti uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ, no akatan’ti.
dn24:2.13.8.eng: ‘Clearly, sir, a superhuman demonstration of psychic power has been performed.’

dn24:2.13.9.pli: ‘Evampi kho maṃ tvaṃ, moghapurisa, uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karontaṃ evaṃ vadesi—
dn24:2.13.9.eng: ‘Though I perform such a superhuman demonstration of psychic power you say this:

dn24:2.13.10.pli: na hi pana me, bhante, bhagavā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ karotīti.
dn24:2.13.10.eng: “But sir, the Buddha never performs any superhuman demonstrations of psychic power for me.”

dn24:2.13.11.pli: Passa, moghapurisa, yāvañca te idaṃ aparaddhan’ti.
dn24:2.13.11.eng: See how far you have strayed!’

dn24:2.13.12.pli: Evampi kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto mayā vuccamāno apakkameva imasmā dhammavinayā, yathā taṃ āpāyiko nerayiko.
dn24:2.13.12.eng: Though I spoke to Sunakkhatta like this, he still left this teaching and training, like someone on the highway to hell.

dn24:2.14.0.eng: 6. On Describing the Origin of the World

dn24:2.14.1.eng: Bhaggava, I understand the origin of the world.

dn24:2.14.2.pli: Tañca pajānāmi, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāmi, tañca pajānaṃ na parāmasāmi, aparāmasato ca me paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā, yadabhijānaṃ tathāgato no anayaṃ āpajjati.
dn24:2.14.2.eng: I understand this, and what goes beyond it. Yet since I do not misapprehend that understanding, I have realized quenching within myself. Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.
dn24:2.14.2.comm: Compare DN 1:1.36.3. The following passage is largely adapted from the Brahmajālasutta.

dn24:2.14.3.pli: Santi, bhaggava, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā issarakuttaṃ brahmakuttaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapenti.
dn24:2.14.3.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who describe the origin of the world in their tradition as created by the God Almighty, by the Divinity.

dn24:2.14.4.eng: I go up to them and say,

dn24:2.14.5.pli: ‘saccaṃ kira tumhe āyasmanto issarakuttaṃ brahmakuttaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti?
dn24:2.14.5.eng: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’

dn24:2.14.6.pli: Te ca me evaṃ puṭṭhā, ‘āmo’ti paṭijānanti.

dn24:2.14.8.pli: ‘kathaṃvihitakaṃ pana tumhe āyasmanto issarakuttaṃ brahmakuttaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti?
dn24:2.14.8.eng: ‘But how do you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about as created by the God Almighty, by the Divinity?’

dn24:2.14.9.pli: Te mayā puṭṭhā na sampāyanti, asampāyantā mamaññeva paṭipucchanti.
dn24:2.14.9.eng: But they are stumped by my question, and they even question me in return.

dn24:2.14.11.pli: ‘Hoti kho so, āvuso, samayo yaṃ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṃ loko saṃvaṭṭati.
dn24:2.14.11.eng: ‘There comes a time when, reverends, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos contracts.

dn24:2.14.12.pli: Saṃvaṭṭamāne loke yebhuyyena sattā ābhassarasaṃvattanikā honti.
dn24:2.14.12.eng: As the cosmos contracts, sentient beings are mostly headed for the realm of streaming radiance.

dn24:2.14.13.pli: Te tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti.
dn24:2.14.13.eng: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

dn24:2.15.1.pli: Hoti kho so, āvuso, samayo yaṃ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṃ loko vivaṭṭati.
dn24:2.15.1.eng: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos expands.

dn24:2.15.2.eng: As it expands an empty mansion of divinity appears.

dn24:2.15.3.pli: Atha kho aññataro satto āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā suññaṃ brahmavimānaṃ upapajjati.
dn24:2.15.3.eng: Then a certain sentient being—due to the running out of their lifespan or merit—passes away from that host of radiant deities and is reborn in that empty mansion of divinity.

dn24:2.15.4.pli: So tattha hoti manomayo pītibhakkho sayampabho antalikkhacaro subhaṭṭhāyī, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhati.
dn24:2.15.4.eng: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

dn24:2.16.1.pli: Tassa tattha ekakassa dīgharattaṃ nivusitattā anabhirati paritassanā uppajjati—
dn24:2.16.1.eng: But after staying there all alone for a long time, they become dissatisfied and anxious,

dn24:2.16.2.pli: aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṃ āgaccheyyunti.
dn24:2.16.2.eng: “Oh, if only other beings would come to this place.”

dn24:2.16.3.pli: Atha aññepi sattā āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā suññaṃ brahmavimānaṃ upapajjanti tassa sattassa sahabyataṃ.
dn24:2.16.3.eng: Then other sentient beings—due to the running out of their lifespan or merit—pass away from that host of radiant deities and are reborn in that mansion of divinity in company with that being.
dn24:2.16.3.comm: Text has suññaṁ, but this appears to be a mistake, since the mansion is no longer “empty” as Brahmā is already there. Follow DN 1:2.4.3, which lacks suññaṁ.

dn24:2.16.4.pli: Tepi tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti.
dn24:2.16.4.eng: There they too are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

dn24:2.17.1.pli: Tatrāvuso, yo so satto paṭhamaṃ upapanno, tassa evaṃ hoti—
dn24:2.17.1.eng: Now, the being who was reborn there first thinks,

dn24:2.17.2.pli: ahamasmi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ, mayā ime sattā nimmitā.
dn24:2.17.2.eng: “I am the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power,  God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born. And these beings were created by me.

dn24:2.17.5.pli: aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṃ āgaccheyyunti;
dn24:2.17.5.eng: ‘Oh, if only other beings would come to this place.’

dn24:2.17.6.pli: iti mama ca manopaṇidhi. Ime ca sattā itthattaṃ āgatāti.
dn24:2.17.6.eng: Such was my heart’s wish, and then these creatures came to this place.”

dn24:2.17.7.pli: Yepi te sattā pacchā upapannā, tesampi evaṃ hoti—
dn24:2.17.7.eng: And the beings who were reborn there later also think,

dn24:2.17.8.pli: ayaṃ kho bhavaṃ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ;
dn24:2.17.8.eng: “This must be the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.

dn24:2.17.9.eng: And we were created by him.

dn24:2.17.11.pli: Imañhi mayaṃ addasāma idha paṭhamaṃ upapannaṃ; mayaṃ panāmha pacchā upapannāti.
dn24:2.17.11.eng: Because we see that he was reborn here first, and we arrived later.”

dn24:2.17.12.pli: Tatrāvuso, yo so satto paṭhamaṃ upapanno, so dīghāyukataro ca hoti vaṇṇavantataro ca mahesakkhataro ca.
dn24:2.17.12.eng: And the being who was reborn first is more long-lived, beautiful, and illustrious than those who arrived later.

dn24:2.17.13.pli: Ye pana te sattā pacchā upapannā, te appāyukatarā ca honti dubbaṇṇatarā ca appesakkhatarā ca.

dn24:2.17.14.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, vijjati, yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
dn24:2.17.14.eng: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.

dn24:2.17.15.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
dn24:2.17.15.eng: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn24:2.17.16.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati; tato paraṃ nānussarati.
dn24:2.17.16.eng: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.

dn24:2.17.18.pli: “yo kho so bhavaṃ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ, yena mayaṃ bhotā brahmunā nimmitā. So nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassati.
dn24:2.17.18.eng: “He who is the Divinity—the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born—by he we were created. He is permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.
