dn24:2.17.19.pli: Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā tena bhotā brahmunā nimmitā, te mayaṃ aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā”ti.
dn24:2.17.19.eng: We who were created by that Divinity are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, liable to pass away, and have come to this place.”

dn24:2.17.20.pli: Evaṃvihitakaṃ no tumhe āyasmanto issarakuttaṃ brahmakuttaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti.
dn24:2.17.20.eng: Is this how you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about as created by the God Almighty, by the Divinity?’
dn24:2.17.20.comm: This statement is not explicitly phrased as a question, but the Mahāsaṅgīti edition inconsistently punctuates it as one. It makes more sense in context, especially as a response to the initial question: Kathaṁvihitakaṁ (“How do you describe …”) … Evaṁvihitakaṁ (“Is this how you describe …”).

dn24:2.17.22.pli: ‘evaṃ kho no, āvuso gotama, sutaṃ, yathevāyasmā gotamo āhā’ti.
dn24:2.17.22.eng: ‘That is what we have heard, Reverend Gotama, just as you say.’
dn24:2.17.22.comm: This is adopted from DN 1:2.2.1. These philosophers belong with the “partial eternalists”.

dn24:2.17.23.eng: Bhaggava, I understand the origin of the world.

dn24:2.17.24.pli: Tañca pajānāmi, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāmi, tañca pajānaṃ na parāmasāmi, aparāmasato ca me paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā. Yadabhijānaṃ tathāgato no anayaṃ āpajjati.
dn24:2.17.24.eng: I understand this, and what goes beyond it. Yet since I do not misapprehend that understanding, I have realized quenching within myself. Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.

dn24:2.18.1.pli: Santi, bhaggava, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā khiḍḍāpadosikaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapenti.
dn24:2.18.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who describe the origin of the world in their tradition as due to those depraved by play.

dn24:2.18.2.eng: I go up to them and say,

dn24:2.18.3.pli: ‘saccaṃ kira tumhe āyasmanto khiḍḍāpadosikaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti?
dn24:2.18.3.eng: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’

dn24:2.18.4.pli: Te ca me evaṃ puṭṭhā ‘āmo’ti paṭijānanti.

dn24:2.18.6.pli: ‘kathaṃvihitakaṃ pana tumhe āyasmanto khiḍḍāpadosikaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti?
dn24:2.18.6.eng: ‘But how do you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about due to those depraved by play?’

dn24:2.18.7.pli: Te mayā puṭṭhā na sampāyanti, asampāyantā mamaññeva paṭipucchanti,
dn24:2.18.7.eng: But they are stumped by my question, and they even question me in return.

dn24:2.18.9.pli: ‘Santāvuso, khiḍḍāpadosikā nāma devā. Te ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharanti. Tesaṃ ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati sammussati, satiyā sammosā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
dn24:2.18.9.eng: ‘Reverends, there are gods named “depraved by play”. They spend too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. And in doing so, they lose their mindfulness, and they pass away from that host of gods.

dn24:2.18.10.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, vijjati, yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati,
dn24:2.18.10.eng: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.

dn24:2.18.11.pli: itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati,
dn24:2.18.11.eng: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn24:2.18.12.pli: agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati; tato paraṃ nānussarati.
dn24:2.18.12.eng: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.

dn24:2.18.14.pli: “ye kho te bhonto devā na khiḍḍāpadosikā te na ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharanti. Tesaṃ nātivelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati na sammussati, satiyā asammosā te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti,
dn24:2.18.14.eng: “The gods not depraved by play don’t spend too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. So they don’t lose their mindfulness, and don’t pass away from that host of gods.

dn24:2.18.15.pli: niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassanti.
dn24:2.18.15.eng: They are permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.

dn24:2.18.16.pli: Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā khiḍḍāpadosikā te mayaṃ ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharimhā, tesaṃ no ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati sammussati, satiyā sammosā evaṃ mayaṃ tamhā kāyā cutā,
dn24:2.18.16.eng: But we who were depraved by play spent too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. In doing so, we lost our mindfulness, and passed away from that host of gods.

dn24:2.18.17.pli: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā”ti.
dn24:2.18.17.eng: We are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, liable to pass away, and have come to this place.”

dn24:2.18.18.pli: Evaṃvihitakaṃ no tumhe āyasmanto khiḍḍāpadosikaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti.
dn24:2.18.18.eng: Is this how you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about due to those depraved by play?’

dn24:2.18.20.pli: ‘evaṃ kho no, āvuso gotama, sutaṃ, yathevāyasmā gotamo āhā’ti.
dn24:2.18.20.eng: ‘That is what we have heard, Reverend Gotama, just as you say.’

dn24:2.18.21.eng: Bhaggava, I understand the origin of the world.

dn24:2.18.22.eng: Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.

dn24:2.19.1.pli: Santi, bhaggava, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā manopadosikaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapenti.
dn24:2.19.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who describe the origin of the world in their tradition as due to those who are malevolent.

dn24:2.19.2.eng: I go up to them and say,

dn24:2.19.3.pli: ‘saccaṃ kira tumhe āyasmanto manopadosikaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti?
dn24:2.19.3.eng: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’

dn24:2.19.4.pli: Te ca me evaṃ puṭṭhā ‘āmo’ti paṭijānanti.

dn24:2.19.6.pli: ‘kathaṃvihitakaṃ pana tumhe āyasmanto manopadosikaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti?
dn24:2.19.6.eng: ‘But how do you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about due to those who are malevolent?’

dn24:2.19.7.pli: Te mayā puṭṭhā na sampāyanti, asampāyantā mamaññeva paṭipucchanti.
dn24:2.19.7.eng: But they are stumped by my question, and they even question me in return.

dn24:2.19.9.pli: ‘Santāvuso, manopadosikā nāma devā. Te ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyanti. Te ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsenti. Te aññamaññaṃ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
dn24:2.19.9.eng: ‘Reverends, there are gods named “malevolent”. They spend too much time gazing at each other, so they grow angry with each other, and their bodies and minds get tired. They pass away from that host of gods.

dn24:2.19.10.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, vijjati, yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
dn24:2.19.10.eng: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.

dn24:2.19.11.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
dn24:2.19.11.eng: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn24:2.19.12.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati.
dn24:2.19.12.eng: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.

dn24:2.19.14.pli: “ye kho te bhonto devā na manopadosikā te nātivelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyanti. Te nātivelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni nappadūsenti. Te aññamaññaṃ appaduṭṭhacittā akilantakāyā akilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti,
dn24:2.19.14.eng: “The gods who are not malevolent don’t spend too much time gazing at each other, so they don’t grow angry with each other, their bodies and minds don’t get tired, and they don’t pass away from that host of gods.

dn24:2.19.15.pli: niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassanti.
dn24:2.19.15.eng: They are permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.

dn24:2.19.16.pli: Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā manopadosikā, te mayaṃ ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyimhā. Te mayaṃ ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsimhā. Te mayaṃ aññamaññaṃ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Evaṃ mayaṃ tamhā kāyā cutā,
dn24:2.19.16.eng: But we who were malevolent spent too much time gazing at each other, so our minds grew angry with each other, our bodies and minds got tired, and we passed away from that host of gods.

dn24:2.19.17.pli: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā”ti.
dn24:2.19.17.eng: We are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, liable to pass away, and have come to this place.”

dn24:2.19.18.pli: Evaṃvihitakaṃ no tumhe āyasmanto manopadosikaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti.
dn24:2.19.18.eng: Is this how you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about due to those who are malevolent?’

dn24:2.19.20.pli: ‘evaṃ kho no, āvuso gotama, sutaṃ, yathevāyasmā gotamo āhā’ti.
dn24:2.19.20.eng: ‘That is what we have heard, Reverend Gotama, just as you say.’

dn24:2.19.21.eng: Bhaggava, I understand the origin of the world.

dn24:2.19.22.eng: Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.

dn24:2.20.1.pli: Santi, bhaggava, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapenti.
dn24:2.20.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who describe the origin of the world in their tradition as having arisen as an anomaly.

dn24:2.20.2.eng: I go up to them and say,

dn24:2.20.3.pli: ‘saccaṃ kira tumhe āyasmanto adhiccasamuppannaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti?
dn24:2.20.3.eng: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’

dn24:2.20.4.pli: Te ca me evaṃ puṭṭhā ‘āmo’ti paṭijānanti.

dn24:2.20.6.pli: ‘kathaṃvihitakaṃ pana tumhe āyasmanto adhiccasamuppannaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti?
dn24:2.20.6.eng: ‘But how do you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about anomalously?’

dn24:2.20.7.pli: Te mayā puṭṭhā na sampāyanti, asampāyantā mamaññeva paṭipucchanti.
dn24:2.20.7.eng: But they are stumped by my question, and they even question me in return.

dn24:2.20.10.pli: Saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
dn24:2.20.10.eng: When perception arises they pass away from that host of gods.

dn24:2.20.11.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, vijjati yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
dn24:2.20.11.eng: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.

dn24:2.20.12.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
dn24:2.20.12.eng: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn24:2.20.13.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ saññuppādaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati’.
dn24:2.20.13.eng: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect the arising of perception, but no further.

dn24:2.20.15.eng: “The self and the cosmos arose anomalously.

dn24:2.20.17.pli: Ahañhi pubbe nāhosiṃ, somhi etarahi ahutvā santatāya pariṇato’ti.
dn24:2.20.17.eng: Because formerly I didn’t exist, whereas now, having not existed, I’ve transformed into the state of existing.”

dn24:2.20.18.pli: ‘Evaṃvihitakaṃ no tumhe āyasmanto adhiccasamuppannaṃ ācariyakaṃ aggaññaṃ paññapethā’ti?
dn24:2.20.18.eng: Is this how you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about anomalously?’

dn24:2.20.20.pli: ‘evaṃ kho no, āvuso gotama, sutaṃ yathevāyasmā gotamo āhā’ti.
dn24:2.20.20.eng: ‘That is what we have heard, Reverend Gotama, just as you say.’

dn24:2.20.21.pli: Aggaññañcāhaṃ, bhaggava, pajānāmi tañca pajānāmi, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāmi, tañca pajānaṃ na parāmasāmi, aparāmasato ca me paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
dn24:2.20.21.eng: I understand this, and what goes beyond it. Yet since I do not misapprehend that understanding, I have realized quenching within myself. Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.

dn24:2.21.1.pli: Evaṃvādiṃ kho maṃ, bhaggava, evamakkhāyiṃ eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā asatā tucchā musā abhūtena abbhācikkhanti:
dn24:2.21.1.eng: Though I state and assert this, certain ascetics and brahmins misrepresent me with the incorrect, hollow, false, untruthful claim:

dn24:2.21.2.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has a distorted perspective, and so have his monks.

dn24:2.21.4.pli: yasmiṃ samaye subhaṃ vimokkhaṃ upasampajja viharati, sabbaṃ tasmiṃ samaye asubhantveva pajānātī’ti.
dn24:2.21.4.eng: “When one enters and remains in the liberation of the beautiful, at that time one only perceives what is ugly.”’

dn24:2.21.5.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ, bhaggava, evaṃ vadāmi:

dn24:2.21.6.pli: ‘yasmiṃ samaye subhaṃ vimokkhaṃ upasampajja viharati, sabbaṃ tasmiṃ samaye asubhantveva pajānātī’ti.

dn24:2.21.8.pli: ‘yasmiṃ samaye subhaṃ vimokkhaṃ upasampajja viharati, subhantveva tasmiṃ samaye pajānātī’”ti.
dn24:2.21.8.eng: ‘When one enters and remains in the liberation of the beautiful, at that time one only perceives what is beautiful.’”

dn24:2.21.9.pli: “Te ca, bhante, viparītā, ye bhagavantaṃ viparītato dahanti bhikkhavo ca.
dn24:2.21.9.eng: “They are the ones with a distorted perspective, sir, who regard the Buddha and the mendicants in this way.

dn24:2.21.10.pli: Evaṃpasanno ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavati. Pahoti me bhagavā tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ, yathā ahaṃ subhaṃ vimokkhaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan”ti.
dn24:2.21.10.eng: Sir, I am quite confident that the Buddha is capable of teaching me so that I can enter and remain in the liberation on the beautiful.”

dn24:2.21.11.pli: “Dukkaraṃ kho etaṃ, bhaggava, tayā aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena subhaṃ vimokkhaṃ upasampajja viharituṃ.
dn24:2.21.11.eng: “It’s hard for you to enter and remain in the liberation on the beautiful, since you have a different view, creed, and belief, unless you dedicate yourself to practice with the guidance of tradition.

dn24:2.21.12.pli: Iṅgha tvaṃ, bhaggava, yo ca te ayaṃ mayi pasādo, tameva tvaṃ sādhukamanurakkhā”ti.
dn24:2.21.12.eng: Come now, Bhaggava, carefully preserve the confidence that you have in me.”

dn24:2.21.13.pli: “Sace taṃ, bhante, mayā dukkaraṃ aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena subhaṃ vimokkhaṃ upasampajja viharituṃ.
dn24:2.21.13.eng: “If it’s hard for me to enter and remain in the liberation on the beautiful, since I have a different view, creed, and belief, unless I dedicate myself to practice with the guidance of tradition,

dn24:2.21.14.pli: Yo ca me ayaṃ, bhante, bhagavati pasādo, tamevāhaṃ sādhukamanurakkhissāmī”ti.
dn24:2.21.14.eng: I shall carefully preserve the confidence that I have in the Buddha.”

dn24:2.21.15.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn24:2.21.16.pli: Attamano bhaggavagotto paribbājako bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
dn24:2.21.16.eng: Satisfied, the wanderer of the Bhaggava clan approved what the Buddha said.
